content:
The Clerk of the House of Commons is a highly experienced and professional official who is expected to act impartially and without bias. They are required to provide neutral and accurate advice to all Members of Parliament, regardless of their party affiliation or personal beliefs.

While it is possible that the Clerk may have personal opinions or feelings towards certain Members of Parliament or political parties, these must be put aside when performing their duties. The Clerk is bound by their oath of impartiality and is required to act in the best interests of the House of Commons as a whole, rather than any particular individual or group.

In addition, there are various mechanisms in place to ensure that the Clerk remains impartial in their role. They are accountable to the Speaker of the House of Commons, and their guidance and advice must be consistent with parliamentary precedent, procedure and conventions. The Clerk's advice is also subject to review by parliamentary committees and can be challenged by Members of Parliament if they believe it to be incorrect or biased.

Overall, the impartiality of the Clerk of the House of Commons is crucial to the effective functioning of Parliament, and there are safeguards in place to ensure that their advice and guidance are always neutral and impartial.
